Created an attachment (id=81004)
Factory unsupported error patch

Hi... This patch includes a variation that might trap what's going on with the unsupported error you're seeing. I think it's due to the fact that the factory must be coming in without an id for some reason or perhaps the factory is null itself. In either case, this additional error handling in that area should take care of it. Can you test it for me since I can't seem to duplicate it here?

--Fitz

Hi Brian,

I applied the patch, but eventually got the same UnsupportedOperationException.
Note that I am often launching from a debug session within eclipse and will just terminate the application instead of shutting down cleanly.  Maybe that is coming into play, not sure.

Hey Tom...

Is there any way to narrow this down some to determine what type of profile is 
causing the error? At this point since I can't reproduce the issue, I'm just poking at things trying to see if anything is the root cause and can't diagnose properly... So maybe put a breakpoint in the code where the exception gets thrown and leave it there, waiting for it to happen... 

I just need more information to get this narrowed down. 

Sorry for the delay... Needle... Haystack... You know how it goes.

--Fitz
BTW... Are you using the Sun JVM or the IBM JVM for JDK 1.5?
Hmmm... good question.  I use both, but generally IBM JVM for JDK 1.5.  I'll make certain note of it the next time it happens.

I stopped the debugger on this exception.  It is occurring when I bring up the workspace  (I have a Dali JPA project in the workspace) at this line:

mConnectionFactories.put(icfap.getId(), icfap);

Here's the values:
mConnectionFactories = Collections$EmptyMap
icfap.getId = "java.sql.Connection"

I think the issue is that mConnectionFactories is an EmptyMap and put(...) is being called, which is invalid.  From the AbstractMap.put javadoc:
 * @exception UnsupportedOperationException
 *                when adding to this Map is not supported


It looks like the ConnectionProfileProvider(String id) constructor sets it to an Emptymap, and the init() method sets it to a new HashMap().  

The init() call is only called from the other constructor: ConnectionProfileProvider(IConfigurationElement element);

So I'm guessing in this scenario, the ConnectionProfileProvider(String id) constructor is being used and not initializing the mConnectionFactories map.  

Let me know if that helps, or what other debugging I can do.

Hi Brian,

That did seem to work after I made a similar check in addProfileExtension
if ( mProfileExtensions == Collections.EMPTY_MAP ) {
	mProfileExtensions = new HashMap();
}
mProfileExtensions.put(pe.getId(), pe);


As I was getting another NPE:
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
	at java.util.AbstractMap.put(Unknown Source)
	at org.eclipse.datatools.connectivity.internal.ConnectionProfileProvider.addProfileExtension(ConnectionProfileProvider.java:194)
	at org.eclipse.datatools.connectivity.internal.ConnectionProfileManager.processExtensions(ConnectionProfileManager.java:189)
	at org.eclipse.datatools.connectivity.internal.ConnectionProfileManager.getProviders(ConnectionProfileManager.java:91)
	at org.eclipse.datatools.connectivity.internal.ConnectionProfileManager.getProvider(ConnectionProfileManager.java:96)
	at org.eclipse.datatools.connectivity.internal.ConnectionProfile.<init>(ConnectionProfile.java:103)

That seemed to allow the workspace to start up and the connections were still intact.  Sorry I can't tell more about the root cause that actually causes this state though.  These checks should hopefully be enough to handle the condition at least.
I am resolving this defect because it appears to have been fixed.  Please re-open the defect if this is still an issue.
